body: While I understand what the `pwd -P` is doing, isn't the way @dtrebbien suggests simpler and possibly preferred - at the moment, unless I'm missing something, the existing launch script doesn't `cd` before executing?

The main issue with the suggested approach is that if we execute the script in `~`, it will look for the executable at `~/../Resources/"${app.name}"/bin/"${app.name}"`, so you need to `cd` to the directory first. The symlink works, but `codesign` doesn't like it when the "main executable" is a symlink, so the one I provided `cd`s to `../Resources/"${app.name}"/bin`.
As for what `${0%/*}` is, see https://stackoverflow.com/q/6393551/1366594
I did just notice that I try to change to the bin dir before getting the real directory of the script. That might need to be tested in the case that the new mac bin script is symlinked.

@SirIntellegence oops, yes, missed that.  But maybe it needs to resolve to an absolute path without `cd` ing to the directory?  I'm not sure of the implication of changing directory, but that would be a behavioural change I think - the launcher doesn't `cd` from what I remember, it resolves to an absolute path to execute.  Can't we do same here to resolve, copying the existing path resolution from the top of the launcher?
I fixed most of the requested changes now.
So I'd say we can merge this, correct?

The changeset look good - I just did a test build and it resulted in a netbeans image, that was able to execute ant projects with the build-in ant version.
I think it would be good to get this merged.
FWIW, I've rebased the patch on top of Jarda's PR #555, and dropped the additional change to spi.editor.hints, but otherwise it should be the same as before.

To answer the question about the userdir and cachedir, these are not updated by this patch. Branding like this includes:
-the userdir and cache dir
-splash screen
-window title

I think that in the past, even RCs had their own userdirs, splash screen updates, etc. So next time, we should do that before attempting a release, guess (currently it is unclear if there will be a respin on RC1 or not - if yes, we can prepare a branding patch to update the above to 9.0rc1, otherwise we should update that before either next RC or FCS.)
If there is not any problem, I'll merge this tomorrow.

HeurÃ©ka, after 9089711 we have a working build with `platform` cluster being in its own subdirectory and without changes to the `nbbuild/*.properties` files:
```bash
$ git diff -r origin/master -- cluster.properties
$ git diff -r origin/master -- build.properties
$ git log | head -n 4
commit 90897110b29aa242a5610babce7f59cae71579cf
```
next step is to fix `apisupport.*` modules to work with this new layout. Then I prepare  the infrastructure changes (without shuffling files around) into own #564 and try to integrate those first. Once the IDE with the enhanced support is widely used, we can perform the shuffling.
I don't believe we need a notice at all. NOTICE.txt in ini4j is just a license statement. It's not a notice from an Apache process pow.

Your argument would also work against the ASF requirement, that the NOTICE file of ASF project contains the project name, the copyright notice and the ASF attribution. I don't see the big difference here.

From my reading of https://www.apache.org/legal/src-headers.html#notice which points to http://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#required-third-party-notices I don't believe we can consider that file a 'required third-party notice'. It's just stating the license of the project.

Also read http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html#mod-notice which mentions

>NOTICE is reserved for a certain subset of legally required notifications which are not satisfied by either the text of LICENSE or the presence of licensing information embedded within the bundled dependency.

And actually, the Apache License 4d mentions that:

>(d) If the Work includes a "NOTICE" text file as part of its
          distribution, then any Derivative Works that You distribute must
          include a readable copy of the attribution notices contained
          within such NOTICE file, excluding those notices that do not
          pertain to any part of the Derivative Works

But note that according to the license definitions:

>"Derivative Works" shall mean any work, whether in Source or Object
      form, that is based on (or derived from) the Work and for which the
      editorial revisions, annotations, elaborations, or other modifications
      represent, as a whole, an original work of authorship. For the purposes
      of this License, Derivative Works shall not include works that remain
      separable from, or merely link (or bind by name) to the interfaces of,
      the Work and Derivative Works thereof.

So, since NetBeans just 'links' to ini4j we are not making a Derivative Work and we don't even have to follow 4d.

All you are saying is true for allmost any dependency of netbeans. Netbeans is no derivate of apache commons-net, apache commons-compress or whatever dependency. Nonetheless we add the notices.

You raised NETBEANS-829 - what was you expected result? There is a NOTICE file, that notice file holds one relevant line: The Copyright (year + name) of the author. Having no other basis, I'll assume the ASF requires us to include that info. If not what is the issue about?!

Wow, you are right! We do include notices for plain dependencies we only link with.

Then, indeed, we should add this one too...

I think when the 2nd donation hits you will have to re-add these licenses since all the newly donated modules will use CDDL and GPL w/CPE. Maybe library wrappers will be GPL w/CPE only.

Where do we keep track of the license of the compile time dependencies?
@emilianbold: it seems we should not have licenses for anything that is not relevant to releasing the sources, e.g., licenses for compile time dependencies are irrelevant and confusing to Apache.
Thank you for taking time to review this. I'll merge it then.

Yes, so far it is good to be consistent in our approach.

I've also opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/LEGAL/issues/LEGAL-389 to clarify if the 4d and Derivative Work interpretation might be correct. If it is we can go back to all Apache licensed dependencies and remove them from NOTICE.

Regarding 2nd donation: I think it is difficult to estimate what exactly will happen then. But if we push the new modules into the repository, then I assume we will:
a) relicense the sources to Apache
b) for any dependency that is CDDL+GPL, we will choose CDDL (i.e. no need to have CDDL+GPL)
c) we cannot release with hard runtime dependency on/bundle GPL library. So any GPL library will either need to be removed, upgraded to a version with a more acceptable license, or handled in some other way
d) even if the new modules are part of the same repository, we will run verify-libs-and-licenses, rat and other checks only on the basic cluster config, i.e. the new modules don't need to be perfect at the beginning, as they won't be checked. So there will be time to fix them into a releasable state.

Regarding where do we track the licenses, the answer is nowhere. I tried to explain why I think having the license for compile-time dependencies is important here:
https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/incubator-general/201805.mbox/%3cCALd=3dFUbGVs-BXGf3JPoirWFcPMCnbaKKgxkgcYL2M4PCpxBw@mail.gmail.com%3e

And it was rejected here:
https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/incubator-general/201805.mbox/%3CE30631C0-2449-4520-8BB8-8F5F2B3DA7C1%40classsoftware.com%3E

So, frankly, I am not sure what alternative there is other than to remove the licenses (and hence not track the licenses of the compile-time dependencies)? I.e. the opinion of the reviewers appears to be very clear and I don't see many alternatives.

> @emilianbold: it seems we should not have licenses for anything that is not relevant to releasing the sources, e.g., licenses for compile time dependencies are irrelevant and confusing to Apache.

>Regarding where do we track the licenses, the answer is nowhere.  [...]

I think there is great value in keeping track of licensing for all kinds of dependencies, including compile-time.

We just need to flag which ones are compile-time and not include the scary licensing info in the source release files.

So it's a matter of just removing some files when building the source release zip.

Not keeping track of licensing for compile-time means we might easily switch something from compile-time to run-time and not even notice.

I agree, that there is value in tracking license information for compile time dependencies and in fact Jan does too. However I tend to agree with Jan, as we are fighting an uphill battle and Jan tried to reason about it with the reviewers and failed as referenced.

The compile-time information is recorded in the "-license.txt" file in external. And they don't/did not end up in the assembled LICENSE/NOTICE file, but the reviewers were confused nonetheless. The machinery for the combination is in:

/nbbuild/antsrc/org/netbeans/nbbuild/extlibs/CreateLicenseSummary.java

That task is invoked from the build script and merges the informations.

I don't consider the approach of the ASF good practice - and at this point I would not move a project to the ASF, but that was/is Oracles decision.

We though I agree there's value in knowing the license, the reviewers apparently don't think so. If there's something in the repository and not in the release zip, some will be opposed to that (and, frankly, in this case I'd tend to agree - the release would then be materially different from what is the repository).

Please note VerifyLibsAndLicenses tries a little to mark cases where the license is missing and shouldn't be.

In any case: the convenience binary is built from the source release (and I believe that's the only sensible thing to do), so if the licenses are stripped while building the source release, we could (accidentally) switch the dependency to runtime about as easily as if the license is nowhere.
+1 to this PR

The filter in `build.xml` removes the two empty lines in the postprocessing from `notice-temp` to `NOTICE`. I only looked at the `notice-temp` output and just did a full build and also checked the final NOTICE file.
I don't see the primary header getting more lines. Other than that it's a good fix.

Sorry - the wording was not precise. Please see the attached screenshot of the comparison: 

- red is what I meant by "primary header" (the netbeans NOTICE) with the two empty lines
- blue are the imported entries from dependencies with the seperating empty lines

![auswahl_001](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2179736/40576205-fba3374c-60f1-11e8-8185-3fbe4365bdec.jpg)

I see. I don't know if we must have some structure inside the NOTICE file but now that I look at this screenshot it would be even more readable if each entry would have some tabs in front.

Example:
```
Apache Ant
Copyright ...

    The sync task is based on code
    taken from etc etc


Apache Commons Compress
Copyright ...

    The file x/y/x has been derived
    from code found on example.com
```

We don't "need" the structure, but we need to assemble a NOTICE file based on our dependencies (at least this is my current understanding) and it needs to be accepted by the reviewers. The final NOTICE file holds information for required notices from the codebase and the dependencies of the project, that are bundled with the files. See http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html#alv2-dep for details.

The approach in netbeans (consisting of modules) was, that each module declares its dependencies (external/binaries) and for each dependency the license ("<artifact>-license.txt" was recorded. This scheme was enhanced for apache netbeans, by also supporting an "<artifact>-notice.txt" file, that holds required notice information.

The notice information of each included module is then merged into the global file, suppressing duplicates. The file is mostly copied verbatim (only multiple empty lines are collapsed into one). To make the suggested indention possible, there would need to be a fixed notice file format. This is not the case (as you saw in the ini4j case), so I stayed with this minimal formating, just makeing grouping of information visible.

OK, I don't have strong feelings about it. Just an extra newline doesn't seem to group very well to me, we might as well use '===' or something. But if it helps you pinpoint dependencies faster, it's fine.

`src/org/netbeans/modules/java/source/remoteapi/RemoteProvider.java.orig` : backup file?

I tried a classic git rebase - I'll make it short: I aborted it, as it ended with a lot of merge conflicts. The history of this PR is long and winding and this makes it hard.

In this case I would try the github "Squash and merge" variant. This should result in one commit in the history.

You could do it by hand:

- checkout master into a working branch lets call it `pr3-merged`
- make sure you have github PRs fetched (in my case the remote is called github) - if so there should be a branch `github/pr/3` which holds the changes from this PR
- merge `github/pr/3` into `pr3-merged`
- create a diff between `master` and `pr3-merged`: `git diff master..pr3-merged > ../pr3.patch` the output can be outputted into a file and that patch is the core of this PR
- now you could switch your clone back to `master`
- delete the `feature/248233-doc-split-actions` branch locally
- checkout master as a new branch `feature/248233-doc-split-actions`
- apply the patch created above via `git apply ../pr3.patch`
- commit the changes
- force push into the existing `feature/248233-doc-split-actions` in the repository `Chris2011`

If you have done it before, this can be done quickly, if not, I would not start in a big repository like netbeans :-)
Looks good.

@matthiasblaesing Thanks a lot for your help!

> In this case I would try the github "Squash and merge" variant. This should result in one commit in the history.

:+1: 
Could you merge this PR if it's OK with Chris?

BTW, diff of this PR is here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/3.diff
So, in this case, Chris might be able to use the following steps:
- Download the diff file as a patch
- Rename the branch: e.g. `git branch -m feature/248233-doc-split-actions-old` 
- Checkout master (see Matthias's comment) 
- Apply the patch (see Matthias's comment)
- Force push (see Matthias's comment. Especially, please note **"in the repository Chris2011"**.)
These changes will not work under JDK 10, they are 11+.
We have not yet dropped support for JDK8, so from my POV this is not mergeable if it is indeed 11 only.

Sure no worries. If it is not merged that is fine. If anything its a heads up for things that will beak under 11. Backward compliance is always difficult. It one of my biggest gripes with Java. But that is up to each project. At least JDK8 is still some what current. Though I am 11 in dev, and 10 in production. I suspect Oracle is wanting to shed some of the legacy stuff as well with the increased releases. I think it will get really interesting for backward compliance. Good luck there!
You could try to find a solution, that works for both worlds 8 + 11.
Chris is a committer, so he can commit himself. @Chris2011 if you need help, feel free to contact me.

Well Unsafe is moving locations so not sure how to address that for both. The other I guess you could add a wrapper to NamedImportScope or something to add back the constructor with 2 arguments and discard the 2nd.

I do not seen any clean solution to either offhand. I will think on it more and see if I can come up with a more elegant solution. But I would not hold my breath. Legacy compatibility is the last thing on my list.

It is likely something a build system will have to switch. Like a java11 folder or something with the modified files, and for the rest can use existing. Short of finding a solution that works for both.

I am not modifying the build aspect with any of my PRs. For many they will need a new import of [javax-annotations](https://github.com/javaee/javax.annotation). A bunch now need that which did not before as it was in the JDK.

The problem is deeper: The classes are also missing at runtime, so just building against java 11 will not help. You can try to use reflection to work around it for now, but _Unsafe#defineClass_ will also go away.

That is good to know. I have not run into any runtime issues yet. But still updating other packages. I have switched other projects over to the new location of Unsafe under JDK11. Even if I can make a work around. I cannot test easily. My env no longer supports JDK8. I am 10+ only.
Sure. Anyway, I wanted to avoid merging it as it is :)
Will try that. Thx.

Is there some README file that could help me build this?

I also don't have Windows but could we perhaps create a Dockerfile to cross-compiles the Windows .exe?

Are the builds reproducible? Would I get the same binary / hashfile for the same .exe?

Sorry, no readme at this time. But not should not be really difficult to build that - on Ubuntu, IIRC I just installed the "mingw-w64" package (version 4.0.4-2), and the run the Makefile.mingw, e.g.:
cd o.n.bootstrap/launcher/windows
make -f Makefile.mingw

I myself probably won't have time to create (or probably even use) a Docker file, but anybody is free to do that.

I don't think the build is reproducible right now; -Wl,--no-insert-timestamp seems to make the exe build reproducible, but not the dll build.

Please note the Unsafe part is only important when running on JDK 8. My plan was to use the reflection if we got to a place where we would use JDK 9+ to compile with "--release 8".

The NamedImportScope may need some reflection handling, unless we drop both 9 and 10 :-(. Ideally, we would rewrite the method to not use the internal class, but not sure if we can do it in near future.

@emilianbold the individual commits were already reviewed when they went into master. From my POV the review requirement is: Do you agree, that this should be merged to release90.
Looks good. Please consider cherry-picking this to release90, the branch that was created to finally release Netbeans 9.0.
@sdedic could you please revisit this?

@matthiasblaesing apologies / thanks for the reminder. Yes, I think that it would be better to add the API method. There are number of situations when UI need to attach to the document, but typically it's desirable to let GC collect unused UI while the data is alive. 
Thanks for your efforts.

Regarding the makefile in o.n.bootstrap/launcher/windows, oops. apparently I forgot to git add it - should be fixed now.

The (new) makefiles are not written (or intended) to be cross-platform. Given we need to recompile the launchers only rarely, I don't think we need a cross-platform build. I think it would be good to settle on a particular platform to do the build (which could be Windows, Linux or some kind of docker image), and do it using that approach. (The advantage of Linux (and docker probably too) is that it is easy to install/run on any other system in some kind of virtualization.)

Regarding sources organization, I think it makes some sense: o.n.bootstrap contains stuff that is platform (i.e. the base launcher); ide contains ide-specific launcher; and apisupport.harness the launcher for custom applications. (There is an unfortunate like from apisupport.harness to ide, which admittedly is a little weird, but otherwise seems to make sense in the modular world.)

Looks like for ```defineClass``` there is [another solution](http://jdk.java.net/11/release-notes#JDK-8193033) that is 9+. Though I think the jdk internal Unsafe is there for 9+ as well. Still this is proper for 11+. I can update the PR for that part. Though likely will not work for 8.
